tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question tests the understanding of the plane strain condition and requires integrating concepts of stress and strain. The difficulty is medium as it requires understanding the definitions and applying them to the given statements.

answer_validation.reasoning: Plane strain is defined by constraints on strain components, not directly on stresses. In plane strain (deformation in the x-y plane): the out-of-plane normal and shear strains are zero, i.e. \(\epsilon_{zz} = 0\), \(\gamma_{xz} = 0\), \(\gamma_{yz} = 0\). This is exactly what statement P says, so P is true. However, even though out-of-plane strains are zero, the corresponding stresses need not be zero. From generalized Hooke\'s law for plane strain, we typically have \(\sigma_{zz} = \nu (\sigma_{xx} + \sigma_{yy})\neq 0\) in general, while \(\tau_{xz} = \tau_{yz} = 0\). Thus, statement Q (all out-of-plane stresses zero) is false, and statement R (only the normal out-of-plane stress may be non-zero, shear components zero) is true. Therefore, the correct combination is P and R, i.e. option D, matching the official key.

step_by_step: Step 1: Recall the definition of plane strain. Deformation is confined to one plane (say x-y), so the strains involving the perpendicular direction z are zero: \(\epsilon_{zz} = 0\), \(\gamma_{xz} = 0\), \(\gamma_{yz} = 0\).

Step 2: Compare this with statement P. It says all points undergo displacements in one plane (x-y), leading to \(\epsilon_{zz} = \gamma_{xz} = \gamma_{yz} = 0\). This matches the standard definition of plane strain, so P is true.

Step 3: Recall the stress state in plane strain. Even though out-of-plane strains are zero, the body can develop out-of-plane normal stress \(\sigma_{zz}\) to enforce \(\epsilon_{zz} = 0\). From generalized Hooke's law, \(\sigma_{zz} = \nu (\sigma_{xx} + \sigma_{yy})\) in plane strain, which is generally non-zero. However, because \(\gamma_{xz} = \gamma_{yz} = 0\), the corresponding shear stresses \(\tau_{xz}\) and \(\tau_{yz}\) are zero.

Step 4: Check statement Q. It claims all stress components perpendicular to the plane (\(\sigma_{zz}, \tau_{xz}, \tau_{yz}\)) are zero. This is the definition of plane stress, not plane strain. Hence Q is false for plane strain.

Step 5: Check statement R. It says that except the normal component, all other stress components perpendicular to the plane are zero: \(\sigma_{zz} \neq 0\), \(\tau_{xz} = \tau_{yz} = 0\). This matches the actual stress state in plane strain, so R is true.
Step 6: Therefore, the correct statements are P and R, corresponding to option D.

key_insights: Plane strain is defined by zero out-of-plane strains, not zero out-of-plane stresses.
In plane strain, \(\sigma_{zz}\) is generally non-zero and determined by the constraint \(\epsilon_{zz} = 0\).
Statement Q actually describes plane stress, which is a common confusion.

industry_examples: Stress analysis of long concrete dams where deformation is essentially in the cross-sectional plane and longitudinal strain is constrained to zero.
Analysis of long underground tunnels or pipelines where a cross-section can be modeled under plane strain due to large length compared to cross-section dimensions.
specific_systems: Gravity dams in civil engineering, where the central vertical section is often treated as a plane strain problem.
Runway or taxiway pavements modeled as long strips under plane strain for cross-sectional analysis.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Choosing the correct idealization (plane stress vs plane strain) directly affects predicted stresses and deflections. Using plane stress instead of plane strain for a thick structure can significantly underestimate stiffness and out-of-plane stresses, leading to unsafe designs.

common_mistakes.mistake: Confusing plane strain with plane stress and assuming all out-of-plane stresses are zero in plane strain.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Both are 2D idealizations and the names are similar, so students often memorize one pattern (all z-stresses zero) and apply it to both.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember: 'plane stress' kills stresses in the perpendicular direction; 'plane strain' kills strains in the perpendicular direction. Always ask yourself: is the body thin (plane stress) or very long/thick (plane strain)?
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to wrong selection of statements (choosing Q instead of R) and incorrect modeling in real problems.

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking that if strain is zero in a direction, then stress must also be zero in that direction.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Intuitive but incorrect belief that no deformation means no stress, ignoring constraints and compatibility.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Recall simple examples: a bar fixed at both ends with temperature rise has zero net strain but non-zero thermal stress. Constraints can create stress even when strain is zero.
common_mistakes.consequence: Misunderstanding of constrained systems and wrong interpretation of plane strain conditions.

common_mistakes.mistake: Ignoring shear components and focusing only on normal components when reading the statements.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Students often pay more attention to \(\sigma_{zz}\) and forget about \(\tau_{xz}, \tau_{yz}\).
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: When analyzing plane stress/strain, systematically list all three perpendicular components: one normal and two shear. Decide for each whether it is zero or not.
common_mistakes.consequence: May incorrectly accept or reject statements Q or R due to overlooking shear terms.

flashcards.front: Define plane strain in the x-y plane in terms of strain components.
flashcards.back: Plane strain in the x-y plane: \(\epsilon_{zz} = 0\), \(\gamma_{xz} = 0\), \(\gamma_{yz} = 0\). Non-zero components: \(\epsilon_{xx}, \epsilon_{yy}, \gamma_{xy}\).

flashcards.front: In plane strain (x-y plane), which out-of-plane stress components are zero and which may be non-zero?
flashcards.back: Typically \(\tau_{xz} = 0\), \(\tau_{yz} = 0\) (since \(\gamma_{xz} = \gamma_{yz} = 0\)), but \(\sigma_{zz} \neq 0\) in general and is given by \(\sigma_{zz} = \nu (\sigma_{xx} + \sigma_{yy})\).

flashcards.front: Which condition (plane stress or plane strain) is more appropriate for a very long dam cross-section and why?
flashcards.back: Plane strain, because deformation in the longitudinal direction is constrained by the surrounding material, so \(\epsilon_{zz} \approx 0\) while in-plane strains are significant.

flashcards.front: True or False: In plane strain, all stresses perpendicular to the plane are zero.
flashcards.back: False. In plane strain, the perpendicular strains are zero, but the normal stress \(\sigma_{zz}\) is generally non-zero; only \(\tau_{xz}\) and \(\tau_{yz}\) are zero.

flashcards.front: Write the expression for \(\sigma_{z}\) in plane strain in terms of \(\sigma_{x}, \sigma_{y}, \nu\).

real_world_context.why_it_matters: If modeled as plane stress instead of plane strain, the predicted stresses and safety factors can be significantly wrong, risking structural failure.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Scan for keywords 'plane strain' vs 'plane stress'. Immediately recall: plane strain \u2192 zero out-of-plane strains; plane stress \u2192 zero out-of-plane stresses. Then match each statement to these definitions. This should take under 1.5 minutes.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure, remember that in constrained thick bodies (plane strain) stresses can exist without strain, so any statement setting all out-of-plane stresses to zero is likely wrong.
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate about 60â€“90 seconds. Do not overthink equations; focus on conceptual definitions and physical examples (thin plate vs long dam) to decide quickly.

alternative_methods.name: Constitutive-law-based reasoning
alternative_methods.description: Instead of relying only on memorized definitions, start from the 3D generalized Hooke's law. Impose \(\epsilon_{z} = 0\), \(\gamma_{xz} = 0\), \(\gamma_{yz} = 0\), and derive which stress components must vanish and which can be non-zero. This confirms that \(\sigma_{z}\) is generally non-zero while \(\tau_{xz}, \tau_{yz}\) are zero.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Deep understanding, less reliance on rote memorization. Cons: Slower and more algebraic, not ideal under tight exam time.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful during preparation or when revising theory, to build strong conceptual foundations.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true about the state of a body in plane strain condition? P: All the points in the body undergo displacements in one plane only, for example the x-y plane, leading to epsilon_zz = gamma_xz = gamma_yz = 0. Q: All the components of stress perpendicular to the plane of deformation, for example the x-y plane, of the body are equal to zero, i.e. sigma_zz = tau_xz = tau_yz = 0. R: Except the normal component, all the other components of stress perpendicular to the plane of deformation of the body, for example the x-y plane, are equal to zero, i.e. sigma_zz != 0, tau_xz = tau_yz = 0.
